Continued safety improvement for the ammonia refrigeration system is a top priority for Ready Pac.  The management plan, internal audits, Process Hazard Analysis studies, as well as our prevention programs are monitored and updated as appropriate to ensure that all elements of our PSM/RMP policy remain accurate and complete.


EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM  

An emergency planning and response policy has been developed at the Ready Pac facility and is maintained by the EHS Manager.  It is based on OSHA requirements for Emergency Action Plan (CCR Title 8, Section 3220) and HAZWOPER (CCR Title 8, Section 5192).  The Emergency Action Plan is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of the PSM/RMP document which is maintained by the EHS Manager at the facility.

This program contains procedures detailing how the facility will respond to accidental ammonia releases and other emergencies.  This program has been coordinated with the Los Angeles County Fire Department and Hazardous Materials Response Teams.

The facility's Emergency Action / Response Policy includes the following elements:

- Key Plant Personnel and Responsibilities
- Outside Agency Notification Contact Information
- Detailed Action Plans for Internal Departments
- First Aid Procedures
- Emergency Medical Treatment Procedures
- Evacuation Plans + Assembly Areas
- Description for Handling Small Ammonia Releases
- Details of Outside Assistance Available 
- Incident Command System
- Initial and Refresher Training


PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The Ready Pac facility has worked to address safety issues as they arise in a continued effort to ensure a safe work environment. Compliance Audits and PHA studies have generated recommendations to improve safety and compliance at the facility. ac facility, including the ammonia system, was designed and constructed in accordance with the recognized industry codes and standards, which specifically outline requirements for the design and operation of ammonia refrigeration systems.  Safety features include ammonia leak detectors in the machinery room, continuous automated ventilation, microprocessor controlled compressors with automatic safety cutouts, ASME certified pressure vessels, and emergency stop controls.  The majority of the ammonia inventory is centrally located inside the machine room.  All pressure-rated vessels are equipped with pressure relief valves that automatically engage in case of a high pressure situation to protect the vessel's integrity.

Ammonia refrigeration systems do not experience any chemical reactions or internal corrosion.  The only composition change that occurs within the systems are phase changes, as ammonia is cycled through various stages of liquid and vapor, similar to the refrigerant in a household refrigerator.  The refrigeration system is a closed-loop system without any regular emissions or releases.  Any leaks are noted and repaired immediately.


FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

EPA's RMP regulation defines accident as the following: 

The release must be from a covered process and involve a regulated substance held above its threshold quantity in the process. The release must have caused at least one of the following: 

- On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (§68.42(a)); or
- Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place (§68.42(a)).

An investigation into the facility's accident history revealed that there have been no releases of ammonia over the past five years (January 2017 - January 2022) that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 100 pounds in 24 hours, or that meet the EPA reporting criteria for the Five-Year Accident History as specified above. ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

To deal with the risks involved with ammonia refrigeration, policies, programs, and procedures have been developed to limit the risks of an accidental ammonia release and/or minimize the consequences of a significant release, fires, explosions, and other types of catastrophic accidents.

Programs developed for the PSM/RMP programs include employee participation, process safety information, process hazard analysis, pre-startup safety review, standard operating procedures, training, management of change, mechanical integrity, hot work permit, contractor management, and incident investigation.  To help coordinate the various elements of the program, a management system has been established that defines responsible parties at the plant for each element of the facility's PSM / RMP program.  Compliance Audits are also conducted every 3 years that can identify potential compliance issues and recommend actions to achieve full compliance.

In the event of an ammonia release, the emergency response plan is coordinated with the local emergency planning commission (LEPC), the County of Los Angeles Fire Department, and the Hazardous Materials Response Team.  The ultimate goal for Ready Pac's PSM/RMP plan is to prevent accidental releases of ammonia, injuries / illnesses, and to avoid physical damage to the environment.  These programs enable our facility to operate a refrigeration system safely because they are based on the rules, procedures, and guidelines that govern our network of ammonia refrigeration facilities, as well as the ammonia refrigeration industry.

The Ready Pac ammonia refrigeration system has many safety features.  Much of the safety of the system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system.  The Ready P

Technical Manager, with the support of the Refrigeration / Utilities Department, are responsible for implementation of the PSM and RMP policies aimed at reducing the risks associated with the ammonia refrigeration system.


STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The ReadyPac facility in Irwindale, CA is a food manufacturing facility and also serves as the headquarters for the ReadyPac operations.  It is located in southern Irwindale off of Irwindale Avenue.  It operates to produce and distribute salad and associated food products.  The facility uses anhydrous ammonia as the refrigerant in the system that provides refrigeration for cold storage, chilling secondary refrigerants, and producing ice.  The maximum intended inventory of ammonia is approximately 49,000 pounds.

The accidental release prevention program starts with good operating and manufacturing practices.  All ammonia process equipment, piping, and valves are inspected on a regular schedule in accordance with manufacturer and industry recommendations.

For example, all compressors are routinely inspected for oil leaks, pressure and temperature gauge calibrations, vibration analysis, oil pressure, and amp reading for motors;  alignment of compressor motors and bearings, filter changes, vibration readings and sensor calibrations;  the condensers are inspected weekly (this includes checking and cleaning nozzles and strainers), motors are greased, fans are checked for cracks, and piping is inspected for leaks;  oil pots are drained (as needed), pump pressures are recorded and pumps and valves are defrosted for excessive ice build-up;  visual inspection for equipment and vessel operating limit conditions, piping and valves are assessed for leaks, integrity, and other potential abnormalities on daily basis;  pressure relief valves are replaced on a five year frequency. ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Ready Pac - Irwindale Facility (Ready Pac), owned by  Bonduelle Fresh Americas, recognizes the facility's responsibility in protecting the public, its employees, the environment, equipment, and property.  Ready Pac is strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety.  This commitment is reflected in a comprehensive accidental release prevention program.  This program addresses the design, installation, operation, maintenance, and employee training associated with the ammonia refrigeration equipment at Ready Pac. 

It is Ready Pac's policy to ensure that controls are in place to limit the risks of potential ammonia releases.  To accomplish the company's goal in controlling accidental losses, the facility has established safety programs that enable plant personnel to: maximize safety performance, reduce risks of handling ammonia and other potentially hazardous substances, and prepare plant personnel to address emergency situations as they might arise.

The Ready Pac facility draws from decades of internal experience and expertise, as well as resources of our parent company, Bonduelle Fresh Americas, to ensure that the appropriate mitigation measures have been identified and are implemented.  The commitment to safety shows in the minimal accident history at the facility.

One of the activities associated with the plant's safety program has been the development and implementation of accidental release prevention and emergency response programs which are designed to comply with Cal-OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (Process Safety Management of Acutely Hazardous Materials, CCR Title 8, Section 5189), and EPA's Risk Management Program regulation (Risk Management Programs for Chemical Accidental Release Prevention, 40 CFR Part 68), as well as the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program (CCR Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, Sections 2735.1 - 2785.1).
